field_edited_text.value:
The steamboat’s speed made the bay’s
raw oysters a feasible cash crop for
delivery in Baltimore and when the process

I(l

for hermetically sealed metal “cans” was
perfected in Baltimore by Thomas Kensett,
Jr., the processing of oysters became a
major industry. By the 1870s Baltimore was
processing upwards of ten million bushels
of oysters a year, and the trade employed
more than 10,000 workers in shucking,
canmaking, printing of labels, and manufac-
turing of boxes. The processing techniques
were used for vegetables as well, and the
city ranked first in the nation in this
industry. The ramifications for the bay’s
economy and society were profound.
Specialized boats were devised for oyster-
ing. Farmers began to plant garden crops
instead of the old staples of tobacco and
wheat. New towns were created along the
shore on what had been wasteland, and
their people looked to Baltimore for a
market and supplies.

The west was still the prize. Balti-
more’s road to Frederick tapped rich farm-
land for the grain and cattle which were
the principal commodities in international
trade, but beyond the Appalachians was
the richer Ohio country which all the East
Coast cities sought to reach. By about 1820
a continuous highway was completed
between Baltimore and the Ohio River. It
was the first complete link between the
East Coast and the Ohio valley.

However, the road was not practical
for moving raw materials on a large scale,
and most of the produce of the Ohio valley
was boated or barged down the Mississippi
River to New Orleans, which became the
fastest-growing city in the United States in
the 1820s. New York’s challenge was the
Erie Canal, a barge waterway between Lake
Erie and the Hudson River, which opened
in 1825 and was instantly successful in
diverting much of the Middle West farm
crops to New York. The freight rate over
the canal was one-tenth the wagon rate.



The Peale Museum, Baltimore
